awd_titl_txt: DISSERTATION RESEARCH: Dietary Ecology of Coastal Coyotes (Canis latrans): Marine-Terrestrial Linkages from Holocene to Present
awd_abstract_narration:
Coyotes are flourishing and expanding their range in North America. In coastal settings, it is possible that marine foods, such as seals or salmon, may be fueling their success. This project will explore the extent to which these types of foods are used by coyotes along the central coast of California, and how growing populations of coyotes impact other predators and their prey.  To assess whether these types of effects are recent and perhaps facilitated by human activity or historical, samples from the same area thousands of years ago will be compared with recently-collected materials.  Samples collected along transects that start at the ocean?s edge and penetrate kilometers inland will be tested in a variety of ways, including analyses of stable isotopes and genetic material.  Data thus far suggest that marine foods are indeed important to modern coyotes, but not to coyotes living in the same area 2000 years ago. If this pattern holds, it would suggest that use of marine resources by contemporary coyotes is a new behavior.

A longer perspective on resource use by coyotes may have important implications for understanding and managing the ecological impacts of modern coyotes, especially in areas where they receive marine and other types of "extra" food, including food inadvertently provided by humans -- garbage and road kill, for example.  Undergraduate students will be involved in the research, gaining valuable field and laboratory skills and being mentored in career development so that they can help solve environmental problems of the future.  In addition, results of this research will be made available to the public through presentations at state parks where the research takes place, as well as through visits to local schools.

por.por_cntn:
Coyotes (Canis latrans) are flourishing and expanding their range in North and Central America. If marine animals, such as seals or salmon, are new and important to coyote diets, then we reasoned that the use of this new resource could be contributing to the success of coyotes. To investigate the impact of marine food on coyote diets, we examined both present-day coyote scat and sub-fossil coyote bones, examining preserved bones and fur in modern scat, and the isotopic chemistry of modern and fossil coyote materials. We found that coyotes at Año Nuevo State Park and Reserve in coastal California eat seals and that seals and other marine foods make up about 20% of their diets over the course of the year. Año Nuevo is exceptional because it is home to a breeding colony of northern elephant seals (Mirounga angustirostris). We did not find evidence for marine resource use by coyotes at two other coastal California sites. We also found no evidence for marine resource use by coyotes in the previous 3000 years; carbon and nitrogen isotope ratios measured in the protein extracted from sub-fossil coyote bones from six coastal archaeological sites revealed that ancient coyotes were relying mostly on terrestrial foods, such as deer, rabbits, and gophers. Our results suggest that the consumption of seals by modern coyotes is a new behavior. This change in behavior is likely a result of relaxed competition with humans as well as grizzly bears, which were driven to extinction in California in the early 1900’s. The marine food used by coyotes at Año Nuevo appears to be positively impacting their population size, though continued work is needed to establish the full effects of this marine subsidy on the coastal ecosystem.

A longer perspective on resource use by coyotes revealed how animals can shift roles in the wake of ecosystem change, such as the loss of a top predator. Their newly gained access to marine resources has implications for range expansion by coyotes; it may be that coastal routes that lack top predators offer coyotes relatively easy pathways by which to extend their territory.

Over the course of this research, we involved a number of undergraduate students in many aspects of the work, giving them an opportunity to gain valuable field and laboratory skills. We also shared our research outcomes with the public through an exhibit at the California Academy of Sciences, as well as through K-12 classroom visits and outreach workshops, including Expanding your Horizons.


Last Modified: 07/31/2015
Modified by: Paul L Koch
